review_title: Great life balance but diminishing returns
job_title: Mission team member in London, England
pros: Nesta supports a really good work life balance, and flex working options. The office is great and is a bit of a privilege to work in location wise. If you're motivated you can use a lot of your time to develop in areas you're interested in. The mission work is of course very purposeful. Nesta's EDI commitments/work is by far the best I've seen in my career. Obviously not perfect yet but I think it's a really welcoming, respectful org that anyone could be happy in. The big comms team means good results get good publicity.
cons: Teams can be very hierarchical, which can be demotivating to junior staff. The lower you are the more likely you'll be doing most of the hands on work, but this then has to be reviewed plenty of times by those above you. And it's unclear what those people are doing in their own work hours. I think it'd be better if teams just worked together on stuff rather than constantly reviewing. Pay not amazing, progression pretty tough, and a lot of the leadership seems pretty vague. The consequence of these things is that if you're a relatively ambitious early career person, you're probably going to 2/3 years max then move somewhere that values you more. But that's common in this industry.

review_title: Works for some but not for all
pros: Nesta has the potential of being a great employer. Lots of intelligent and thoughtful people with a healthy dose of empathy and compassion among staff - you can find great colleagues if you look in the right places. Rather good salaries for a charitable sector (to 'attract talent'), a nice benefits package for a charity, a good office space and flexible working to support work-life balance. Given that Nesta endowment-based, it has also all the potential to generate value-driven innovation, thought leadership, and balance quality and pragmatism in delivering outputs.
cons:
Having seen both the old and the new leadership in action, the new one started off with high ambitious and a promise of focus. As an organisation, it feels somewhat lost though. It could be that the leadership team has a clear plan (lots of politicking and hidden agendas brought into daily operations, so hard to tell) and it's just the rest of the staff that feels a bit lost. Decision making power is concentrated in the hands of just few. 

There's an increasing disconnect between individual teams both vertically and laterally. While there was a lot of change post re-structure, the change continues. Partially in the light of Nesta's acquisition of the Behavioural Insights Team (BIT). It's no longer clear who is running the show - BIT or Nesta. With many key members of Nesta's senior leadership team having joined from BIT, existing staff numbers to be bolstered by BIT secondees, and a strong focus on Nesta integrating with BIT , Nesta seems to be on a mission to be more like BIT. Perhaps that was the plan all along... 

If you don't care much for the plurality of worldview, are committed to tackling big social issues via insights from psychology and behavioural economics, and are seeking for a place to have means to put that all into practice then Nesta is likely to be a place to thrive.

pros: Nice office (not that this is much benefit at the moment).
cons: Anyone thinking of working at Nesta please read the recent reviews. The ones saying that the organisation has changed are right. Having been there for nearly 4 years i can tell you that the organisation has changed dramatically and not for the better. As someone who worked in the third sector before and is of a centre-left political leaning i thought i would fit in. But the new CEO (NOT Geoff Mulgan by the way, he was great) has brought his own political agenda as well as his own staff. He pushed through a big and unnecessary restructuring which saw lots of really talented people leave just so that he could pursue his own agenda (we spent almost a year on an internal strategy consultation which strangely enough ended up with the pet topics which he had suggested the month he arrived). Some other reviews have called him 'woke'. I hesitate to use that term but he is the type who talks constantly about privilege and is not interested in any framing of any problem which does not start from that position. He has divided the staff rather than unifying them (maybe that is a deliberate tactic to make it harder for staff to protest redundancies?) Some staff of a similar political persuasion have been posting five star reviews here to support him. But it is not a happy environment for many of us at the moment and like many people i dont know how much longer i will stay here. That makes me sad since i used to love this place.
